componenttext: Just a quick question, more of a modeling type, but how do you guys think about your long-term effective tax rate going forward? Because I know last year and this year, whether it's the quarter or the trailing 9 months, it's sub-30%. How should we think about that on a sustained basis?

headline: PG&E Corp., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2012
componenttextpreview: Jim, this is Kent. We don't exactly provide guidance on our tax -- effective tax rate in future years. But obviously, the last few years have been very unusual with bonus depreciation, very, very unusual. And at some point, we will see that kind of get ba
componenttext: Jim, this is Kent. We don't exactly provide guidance on our tax -- effective tax rate in future years. But obviously, the last few years have been very unusual with bonus depreciation, very, very unusual. And at some point, we will see that kind of get back to normal going forward. I think the other thing is just, going forward, we do have a lot of questions about what will tax policy be. We don't know whether or not bonus will be continued beyond this year. But then there's lots of other proposals out there for tax policy. So that one's going to be a tough one to wrap our minds around at this point.

headline: PG&E Corp., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2012
componenttextpreview: I think I'd also remind -- this is Gabe. I'd remind everybody that we have said over the last few years, we've had a number of sort of overhanging tax issues that we had settled from many years ago. Those are being worked down very rapidly, and we would e
componenttext: I think I'd also remind -- this is Gabe. I'd remind everybody that we have said over the last few years, we've had a number of sort of overhanging tax issues that we had settled from many years ago. Those are being worked down very rapidly, and we would expect that we would not have that level of tax issues to be working through in the future.

headline: PG&E Corp., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2012
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Anthony Crowdell with Jefferies.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Anthony Crowdell with Jefferies.

headline: PG&E Corp., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2012
componenttextpreview: I guess 2 quick questions, hopefully. When the settlement discussions are going on or when the procedural calendar, I guess, was suspended, there was a date of November 1, where -- I want to know, does the procedural calendar start up again? Just what hap
componenttext: I guess 2 quick questions, hopefully. When the settlement discussions are going on or when the procedural calendar, I guess, was suspended, there was a date of November 1, where -- I want to know, does the procedural calendar start up again? Just what happens on that November 1 date. And the second question, the company seems optimistic, or even the interveners, that a mediator would work best. But the selection of Mitchell's team, definitely created a very charged atmosphere out there in California, I mean, who -- was it the CPUC or was it the utility that was really driving the selection of Mitchell?

headline: PG&E Corp., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2012
componenttextpreview: Well, I'll start off with that second part of that question. It was the CPUC's process selection and contacted the Senator, not the utility. And I'll let Tom comment on the procedural schedule going forward.
componenttext: Well, I'll start off with that second part of that question. It was the CPUC's process selection and contacted the Senator, not the utility. And I'll let Tom comment on the procedural schedule going forward.

headline: PG&E Corp., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2012
componenttextpreview: This is Tom Bottorff from Regulatory Affairs. The only procedural issue at this point for November 1 is waiting for CPUC to report on the progress of the discussion at that point with the ALJs in proceeding. So that's the next significant date in the proc
componenttext: This is Tom Bottorff from Regulatory Affairs. The only procedural issue at this point for November 1 is waiting for CPUC to report on the progress of the discussion at that point with the ALJs in proceeding. So that's the next significant date in the process.

headline: PG&E Corp., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2012
componenttextpreview: Do the hearings start up again? Or the -- like I -- I thought there were still some more hearings to go on maybe like 6 or something like that. Do they start automatically on November 1, or they're still suspended?
componenttext: Do the hearings start up again? Or the -- like I -- I thought there were still some more hearings to go on maybe like 6 or something like that. Do they start automatically on November 1, or they're still suspended?

headline: PG&E Corp., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2012
componenttextpreview: Those hearings are suspended. If they do resume, it wouldn't be until November 26.
componenttext: Those hearings are suspended. If they do resume, it wouldn't be until November 26.

headline: PG&E Corp., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2012
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Travis Miller with Morningstar Securities Research.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Travis Miller with Morningstar Securities Research.

headline: PG&E Corp., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2012
componenttextpreview: Real quick, I wondered if there was any precedent for CPUC for offering a lower ROE on any kind of capital investment.
componenttext: Real quick, I wondered if there was any precedent for CPUC for offering a lower ROE on any kind of capital investment.

headline: PG&E Corp., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2012
componenttextpreview: Travis, this is Kent. We did have experience back in the '90s where the PUC authorized all the utilities to have a lower return on other generation assets, and that's the one that comes to mind for me.
componenttext: Travis, this is Kent. We did have experience back in the '90s where the PUC authorized all the utilities to have a lower return on other generation assets, and that's the one that comes to mind for me.

headline: PG&E Corp., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2012
componenttextpreview: Is there any kind of correlation there that you could use on an appeal basis, or anything involved in that?
componenttext: Is there any kind of correlation there that you could use on an appeal basis, or anything involved in that?

headline: PG&E Corp., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2012
componenttextpreview: I don't know that that decision at the time was appealed by the utilities. It was all part of industry restructuring at the time, wrapped into a very complex dynamic going on in regulation.
componenttext: I don't know that that decision at the time was appealed by the utilities. It was all part of industry restructuring at the time, wrapped into a very complex dynamic going on in regulation.

headline: PG&E Corp., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2012
componenttextpreview: Sure, okay. And then real quick, the financing plan, if that proposed decision were to be approved, would that be pretty much in line with capital expense and operating spec spend? Or would there be some kind of timing issue there in terms of equity and d
componenttext: Sure, okay. And then real quick, the financing plan, if that proposed decision were to be approved, would that be pretty much in line with capital expense and operating spec spend? Or would there be some kind of timing issue there in terms of equity and debt issuance?

headline: PG&E Corp., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2012
componenttextpreview: Well, the proposed decision essentially has similar capital to what we had planned, and it essentially says, "Go ahead and get the work done. You just won't get recovery of all your capital." And on the expense side, again, it's get the work done without
componenttext: Well, the proposed decision essentially has similar capital to what we had planned, and it essentially says, "Go ahead and get the work done. You just won't get recovery of all your capital." And on the expense side, again, it's get the work done without the contingencies that you need to complete the expense amount. I would say on the margin, the impact of the proposed decision, because of the disallowances, on the margin, it will drive somewhat more equity issuance than long-term debt in order to finance the overall program. And essentially, the after tax amounts of the write-ups drive some incremental equity issuance. That's the way to think about it if you're modeling it.

headline: PG&E Corp., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2012
componenttextpreview: Our first -- our next question comes from the line of Dan Eggers with Crédit Suisse.
componenttext: Our first -- our next question comes from the line of Dan Eggers with Crédit Suisse.

headline: PG&E Corp., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2012
componenttextpreview: Just -- yes, maybe 2 mechanical questions. Number one, Kent, could you talk a little bit about how and when you would assess having to revise the expected fine from $200 million to another number?
componenttext: Just -- yes, maybe 2 mechanical questions. Number one, Kent, could you talk a little bit about how and when you would assess having to revise the expected fine from $200 million to another number?

headline: PG&E Corp., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2012
componenttextpreview: I'm sorry, Dan. Can you restate your question? I couldn't hear it all.
componenttext: I'm sorry, Dan. Can you restate your question? I couldn't hear it all.

headline: PG&E Corp., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes. I'm sorry about that. Can you just walk through a little bit the process for reevaluating the level of fine you guys are assuming in your numbers in equity rate, so far as adjusting the $200 million to a new number?
componenttext: Yes. I'm sorry about that. Can you just walk through a little bit the process for reevaluating the level of fine you guys are assuming in your numbers in equity rate, so far as adjusting the $200 million to a new number?

headline: PG&E Corp., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes. Dan, we actually do that assessment every quarter. And essentially, the thought process we go through is we look at all the information available to us, through the regulatory process and otherwise, and to try to assess whether or not $200 million is
componenttext: Yes. Dan, we actually do that assessment every quarter. And essentially, the thought process we go through is we look at all the information available to us, through the regulatory process and otherwise, and to try to assess whether or not $200 million is still at the lower end of a reasonable range. And you can infer from our reporting this quarter and the quarter before and so forth that we've not had a basis for increasing that reserve to this point.

headline: PG&E Corp., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2012
componenttextpreview: Okay. And I guess one other question. Can you just tell us where you are as far as authorization for more equity issuance? I mean, could you turn on the DRIP in the fourth quarter or next year? Is there new authorization that has to occur?
componenttext: Okay. And I guess one other question. Can you just tell us where you are as far as authorization for more equity issuance? I mean, could you turn on the DRIP in the fourth quarter or next year? Is there new authorization that has to occur?

headline: PG&E Corp., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2012
componenttextpreview: If you're talking about the 401(k) and dividend reinvestment, if it's that DRIP, that -- those are our internal programs and that's fine. On the dribble program, we do have authorization. But the program we have, I don't remember exactly how much is left
componenttext: If you're talking about the 401(k) and dividend reinvestment, if it's that DRIP, that -- those are our internal programs and that's fine. On the dribble program, we do have authorization. But the program we have, I don't remember exactly how much is left in it, but it's something like $60 million or $70 million left. Of course, we could replace that with another program when the timing was appropriate.

headline: PG&E Corp., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2012
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Paul Patterson with Glenrock Associates.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Paul Patterson with Glenrock Associates.

headline: PG&E Corp., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2012
componenttextpreview: Just to clarify a few things. The mediator, the other parties are not objecting, you said, to a mediator. Is that -- did they want a mediator? Is that -- do I understand that correctly?
componenttext: Just to clarify a few things. The mediator, the other parties are not objecting, you said, to a mediator. Is that -- did they want a mediator? Is that -- do I understand that correctly?

headline: PG&E Corp., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2012
componenttextpreview: All we can read into is -- if you saw some of their public statements objecting to Senator Mitchell, and a number of the public statements and letters specifically said they don't have a problem with a mediator, I guess it was the selection process for th
componenttext: All we can read into is -- if you saw some of their public statements objecting to Senator Mitchell, and a number of the public statements and letters specifically said they don't have a problem with a mediator, I guess it was the selection process for the Senator that they were concerned with. And so we will be now raising the issue of, okay, are there other mediators, and of course, there are dozens and dozens of very successful mediators out there. And we'll suggest the -- there's a process that we ought to go through and select one.

headline: PG&E Corp., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2012
componenttextpreview: How long do you think that might take?
componenttext: How long do you think that might take?

headline: PG&E Corp., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2012
componenttextpreview: As I said before, I've given up predicting. We'll work it every day.
componenttext: As I said before, I've given up predicting. We'll work it every day.

headline: PG&E Corp., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2012
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then on -- I think Travis was asking a question on the ROE reduction, and you mentioned the generation assets in the 1990s. And as I recall, there was some securitization there. Is there any discussion of securitization as a means of sort of dea
componenttext: Okay. And then on -- I think Travis was asking a question on the ROE reduction, and you mentioned the generation assets in the 1990s. And as I recall, there was some securitization there. Is there any discussion of securitization as a means of sort of dealing with this sort of low ROE asset? Theoretically, there could be a tax benefit for rate payers and what have you. I'm just speaking just in general the securitization. Any of the -- any of this -- the options or -- of strategy that's being discussed at all?

headline: PG&E Corp., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2012
componenttextpreview: No, there hasn't been any discussion like that to date.
componenttext: No, there hasn't been any discussion like that to date.

headline: PG&E Corp., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2012
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just on the actual ROE cost of capital case. The schedule doesn't look like it's changed. So I'm just wondering, given the slippage that we're seeing, not just in your case, just in general, I mean, it seems that the -- the PUC seems to tak
componenttext: Okay. And then just on the actual ROE cost of capital case. The schedule doesn't look like it's changed. So I'm just wondering, given the slippage that we're seeing, not just in your case, just in general, I mean, it seems that the -- the PUC seems to takes some time quite often, more than scheduled. Do you still think we're really -- the schedule still holds for the -- I notice the testimony seemed to be filed and stuff. Just -- do you think it's still going to happen at that time, or any flavor on that?

headline: PG&E Corp., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes. I'm very hopeful that it will. And it's stayed right on schedule. The utilities -- everyone just filed their briefs last week. So it's chugging along. It's a fairly straightforward proceeding really, and we are hopeful that we'll have a final decisio
componenttext: Yes. I'm very hopeful that it will. And it's stayed right on schedule. The utilities -- everyone just filed their briefs last week. So it's chugging along. It's a fairly straightforward proceeding really, and we are hopeful that we'll have a final decision on phase 1 by year end.

headline: PG&E Corp., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2012
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just finally, the Safe Harbor -- there's been a few changes in Safe Harbor statement. And I noticed, I think, the addition of the nuclear issues, potential legislation or regulation, and I know you guys had some seismic stuff going on. But
componenttext: Okay. And then just finally, the Safe Harbor -- there's been a few changes in Safe Harbor statement. And I noticed, I think, the addition of the nuclear issues, potential legislation or regulation, and I know you guys had some seismic stuff going on. But I'm just wondering, I don't believe I saw that last quarter. And I was just wondering, has there been any change that we should be thinking about on that area? It -- with the -- either with respect to seismic or post Fukushima or something like that, that we should be thinking about that has come up?

headline: PG&E Corp., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2012
componenttextpreview: Paul, this is Gabe. It's really just our attempt to make sure that we're adequately covering everything in our disclosures, and specifically with these risk factors.
componenttext: Paul, this is Gabe. It's really just our attempt to make sure that we're adequately covering everything in our disclosures, and specifically with these risk factors.

headline: PG&E Corp., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2012
componenttextpreview: Okay. So there's not anything new that we should be -- that's developed that you're particularly concerned that we should be thinking about?
componenttext: Okay. So there's not anything new that we should be -- that's developed that you're particularly concerned that we should be thinking about?

headline: PG&E Corp., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2012
componenttextpreview: Well, I think we have disclosure. We're actually making progress in getting the approvals to do the seismic testing. So we're moving in the right direction there.
componenttext: Well, I think we have disclosure. We're actually making progress in getting the approvals to do the seismic testing. So we're moving in the right direction there.

headline: PG&E Corp., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2012
componenttextpreview: Our next question is a follow-up question from Michael Lapides with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Our next question is a follow-up question from Michael Lapides with Goldman Sachs.

headline: PG&E Corp., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2012
componenttextpreview: Just a handful of things. First of all, I want to make sure I follow your comments that when I look at Page 9 of the slide deck, the expense you will still show, even if it's more than what's on the slide, you will still show as a nonrecurring item impact
componenttext: Just a handful of things. First of all, I want to make sure I follow your comments that when I look at Page 9 of the slide deck, the expense you will still show, even if it's more than what's on the slide, you will still show as a nonrecurring item impacting earnings. The capital and, therefore, any potential write-offs of capital, you'll show in the lower ROE. The capital write-offs you would show as nonrecurring items. But the lower ROE on which you are allowed to earn on, you will actually include in ongoing EPS.

headline: PG&E Corp., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2012
componenttextpreview: A little different, Michael. The shortfall for expense, and for our recovery of capital, we would show as an item impacting comparability. It just gives you more transparency. You guys can keep track of the pieces that way. The ROE component that reduced
componenttext: A little different, Michael. The shortfall for expense, and for our recovery of capital, we would show as an item impacting comparability. It just gives you more transparency. You guys can keep track of the pieces that way. The ROE component that reduced return on the subsets of our rate base, which is related to the PSEP, that we would just put in earnings because that's really return rather than a cost.

headline: PG&E Corp., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2012
componenttextpreview: Got it, okay. Can you give -- I'm going to change topic off the PSEP a little bit. Can you give an update on the cash flow impacts expected for both Hinkley and the generator settlements?
componenttext: Got it, okay. Can you give -- I'm going to change topic off the PSEP a little bit. Can you give an update on the cash flow impacts expected for both Hinkley and the generator settlements?

headline: PG&E Corp., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2012
componenttextpreview: I think I'll take Hinkley first. In the case of Hinkley, most of what you've been seeing here have been accruals related to the whole house water situation, and those are fairly near term -- and property purchases. So they're fairly near-term items for --
componenttext: I think I'll take Hinkley first. In the case of Hinkley, most of what you've been seeing here have been accruals related to the whole house water situation, and those are fairly near term -- and property purchases. So they're fairly near-term items for -- like the accruals we've done this quarter. When you look at our overall accruals, one is up for Hinkley, there's a significant amount that is really over a very long period of time. That's the remediation of the chromium itself, and that goes on for years. So it really depends which part, but these most recent accruals will be nearer term because we're, essentially, in the process right now of providing those options and the residents have selected them. The second thing in terms of the generator settlements, Gabe, do you want to take that one?

headline: PG&E Corp., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes. Michael, on the generator settlements, there's really no news there other than what we said, I believe, on our last 10-K. And I think as everybody who's followed us knows, there is an overhang of several hundred million dollars or more that will requ
componenttext: Yes. Michael, on the generator settlements, there's really no news there other than what we said, I believe, on our last 10-K. And I think as everybody who's followed us knows, there is an overhang of several hundred million dollars or more that will require financing if all of the remaining generator claims that haven't been settled were settled all at once. That's fairly unlikely. We're having small settlements over time. But at some point, what remains will probably have to be decided by FERC.

headline: PG&E Corp., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2012
componenttextpreview: Okay. And coming back on the Hinkley, just want to make sure I follow. Have the cash flow impacts mirrored the earnings impacts over the last year or so, or are the accruals solely for anticipated future cash flow spending on the more near-term items, Ken
componenttext: Okay. And coming back on the Hinkley, just want to make sure I follow. Have the cash flow impacts mirrored the earnings impacts over the last year or so, or are the accruals solely for anticipated future cash flow spending on the more near-term items, Kent, that you addressed?

headline: PG&E Corp., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2012
componenttextpreview: The cash flow impact, it really only mirrored the accruals reasonably closely. I mean, there's always a little bit of a lag, but it's really for this whole house water and property purchase. And even that, there's somewhat of a lag, certainly within quart
componenttext: The cash flow impact, it really only mirrored the accruals reasonably closely. I mean, there's always a little bit of a lag, but it's really for this whole house water and property purchase. And even that, there's somewhat of a lag, certainly within quarters. It's the final remediation which we've taken significant accrual for, that does not mirror the cash flows at all. The cash flows will be much more gradual on that one.

headline: PG&E Corp., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2012
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Ashar Khan [ph] with Visium Asset Management.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Ashar Khan [ph] with Visium Asset Management.

headline: PG&E Corp., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2012
componenttextpreview: Sorry, I joined a little bit late, Kent, so I don't know if it was addressed. Can you just talk about -- there was a note from the rating agencies that came out last week, which had negative implications from the proposed order. Can you just talk about wh
componenttext: Sorry, I joined a little bit late, Kent, so I don't know if it was addressed. Can you just talk about -- there was a note from the rating agencies that came out last week, which had negative implications from the proposed order. Can you just talk about what your conversation with the rating agencies are? And what is -- in your view, how does the company try to maintain its credit ratings where they are? Is that a focus? Could you share your thoughts there, please?

headline: PG&E Corp., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2012
componenttextpreview: Well, we have been in conversations with the rating agencies once the PD from the PSEP came out. In many ways I like letting the rating agencies speak for themselves in their own reports, and obviously, people have access to the agencies themselves. I wil
componenttext: Well, we have been in conversations with the rating agencies once the PD from the PSEP came out. In many ways I like letting the rating agencies speak for themselves in their own reports, and obviously, people have access to the agencies themselves. I will say the way I look at the issue is it's not simplistically a numerical issue where you just look at our credit ratios. It's not that. I think the rating agencies to me it's more important to really be focusing on the overall appropriateness of the resolution of all the gas issues and whether or not that continues to signal a balanced regulatory environment in California or not. And I think that's really the key indicator that I believe the rating agencies are focused on.

headline: PG&E Corp., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2012
componenttextpreview: Okay. So it's more of a qualitative issue than a quantitative issue?
componenttext: Okay. So it's more of a qualitative issue than a quantitative issue?

headline: PG&E Corp., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2012
componenttextpreview: I think that's fair.
componenttext: I think that's fair.

headline: PG&E Corp., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2012
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then, can I just -- so the time line still remains, right? There's been no change in the time line regarding -- right? There was a November 26 drop-dead date before the OIIs fine was to come out. That still remains intact, is that correct, or am
componenttext: Okay. And then, can I just -- so the time line still remains, right? There's been no change in the time line regarding -- right? There was a November 26 drop-dead date before the OIIs fine was to come out. That still remains intact, is that correct, or am I wrong?

headline: PG&E Corp., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2012
componenttextpreview: That date is scheduled for the end of November. And whether it comes out or not depends on the status or success or progress in the negotiations that are ongoing.
componenttext: That date is scheduled for the end of November. And whether it comes out or not depends on the status or success or progress in the negotiations that are ongoing.

headline: PG&E Corp., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2012
componenttextpreview: Okay. So -- but those dates have not been changed, right?
componenttext: Okay. So -- but those dates have not been changed, right?

headline: PG&E Corp., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2012
componenttextpreview: No.
componenttext: No.

headline: PG&E Corp., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2012
componenttextpreview: There are no additional questions waiting from the phone lines.
componenttext: There are no additional questions waiting from the phone lines.

headline: PG&E Corp., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2012
componenttextpreview: All right. In that case, I will wish everybody a safe day. Please stay inside and make sure you and your family are protected. Thanks very much.
componenttext: All right. In that case, I will wish everybody a safe day. Please stay inside and make sure you and your family are protected. Thanks very much.

headline: PG&E Corp., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2012
componenttextpreview: Thank you, ladies and gentlemen, for attending the Third Quarter Earnings Conference Call. This would now conclude the conference. Please enjoy the rest of your day.
componenttext: Thank you, ladies and gentlemen, for attending the Third Quarter Earnings Conference Call. This would now conclude the conference. Please enjoy the rest of your day.
